content.description: Sit start on the big sloper. Climb straight up.
content.location: Basically the first route on the south face.

content.description:
Same start as

Steinal Tap

, but move up and right on crimps, eliminating the jugs on

Steinal Tap

, to a large, flat jug and make a big move/dynamic move up to a big hold at the lip and top out.
content.protection: 1+ pads and good spotters.  you also may want to climb up the back side or the easier problems too the left to look at the finishing hold.
content.location: Second start left of the little aspen on the south face.

content.description:
Another finger killer.  Same start as

Gertrude Stein

but traverse right to the off-width on crimps.
content.protection: A start pad will protect your backside on the sit start, but you really don't need anything.
content.location: Just to the right of the aspen on the west face of the stein boulder.  Directly in front of you if you come up from the big easy boulder.

content.description:
Traverse across

Slopenstein

and up to the good edges, but instead of moving to the big hold move right across the small edges to the two pebbles next to the aspen tree and then top out.
content.protection: A few pads.  Only one is really necessary, but the more the merrier.
content.location:
It is an extension of

Slopenstein

, the farthest left problem on the west face.

content.description:
Start on a small flat cobble at 2 feet and throw for the smiley face jug and climb jugs up the crack to the top out.  Personally I find it easier than

Warm Up

.
content.protection: A good pad and spotter (there are high feet and some balance required at the top out, not hard, but a scary fall is likely if your hands slip off a cobble).
content.location: It is the second route right of the small aspen on the south face.

content.description: Traverse the low, sloping rail then finish on some crimpers six feet off the ground.
content.location: This is located to the left of the big tree on the west face of the boulder.

content.description: Start at the big low slopers at the arete.  Make a hard move up and left to the pebbles and then a harder, shoulder wrenching move to the pinch/undercling at the roof then use the big flat edges up and left to top out.  If you use the right hand sidepull on the starting sloper the first move is easier, but the crux is the same.
content.protection: A pad and possibly a start pad.
content.location: The route is on the big arete at the southwest corner of the Stein Boulder.  Start under the 6 foot high roof, and climb out the left side.

content.description: Grovel your way up the offwidth.  Climbs easier if you squeeze yourself all the way into the crack and canyoneer your way up it, but hard on your body.
content.location: In the obvious offwidth on the west face of the Stein boulder.

content.description: Start on the big slopers at 1.5 feet and move up through the 6 foot high roof using tough slopers, cobbles and crimps.  Finish straight up the arete.  A shoulder killer, especially if you are shorter.
content.location: Straight up the arete on the southwest corner of the Stein boulder.

content.description:
This has jugs and dynos.  Do the same start as

Melonstein

.  Traverse right across the sloping rail.  Move up to the pocket and diagonal sidepull (the holds on

Warm Up

are off except for the starting sloper).  Move up and right to the smiley face jug on

Steinal Tap

, up and right to a flat jug, down and right to another flat hold and finish right on the big finishing rail of

Golf Ball

.
content.protection: 1, 2, or more pads to protect the cruxes and bad fall from the finish and a spotter to haul them.
content.location: Start on the Southwest arete, and traverse the entire south face.

content.description:
Start matched on the sloper same as

Gertrude Stein

, but instead of climbing up and left, make a few moves out right till you get a good, right hand crimp. From there, make a move up and left to a slick pebble protruding out of the wall. Then jump to the lip for a mellow mantel (the SDS is V9).

Climb the right arete and shallow dihedral on the right side of

Frankenstein

including the cobbles to the right.
content.location: The route starts 5 or 6 feet to the right of the offwidth on the west face of the Stein boulder.

content.description: Start on frightfully small but satisfying crimps at 4 feet high on the far right side of the south face. Move up on slopping cobbles and crimpy pebbles. Throw LEFT hand for the golf ball pebble (you will know it when you see it) and then move up and right to he big juggy rail using the holds to the right of the golf ball. Move right along the rail to top out.
content.location: Far right side of the south face.

content.description:
Start on frightfully small but satisfying crimps at 4 feet high on the far right side of the south face.  Move up on slopping cobbles and crimpy pebbles.  Throw right hand for the golf ball pebble (you will know it when you see it) and then move up and left to he big juggy rail.  Move right along the rail to top out.

There is also a fun variation where you move left hand up to the golf ball and using no other holds to the right, dyno across to the left for the rail.
content.location: Far right side of the south face of the Stein Boulder.

content.description:
Use the same start as

Frankenstein

, traverse left across the offwidth, and continue traversing on good edges. Drop down onto the start hold of

Gertrude Stein

, and finish it out. This adds a few fun moves into

Gertrude Stein

.
content.protection: It has a flat landing, use 2-3 pads.
content.location:
This uses the same start as

Frankenstein

and finishes on

Gertrude Stein

.

content.description: Start on the obvious sloper at 2 feet.  Move up through the flat cobble and pebbles to the jug at the lip.
content.location: Just to the right of the aspen on the West face.  Right in front of you if you come up the trail from the big easy boulder.

content.description: Just right of the offwidth.  Start on twin slopers at two feet.  Slap and hug your way up the two aretes to the pebbles on the ledge.  From there dyno for the finishing hold up and right.  Probably the best problem on the boulder if you have the wingspan.
content.location: The route is on the right side of the offwidth that splits the west face.

content.description:
Start on the sloper at the start of

Gertrude Stein

but move right to tiny edges and dino for the jug at the lip.  Small fingers help.
content.location: Just to the right of the aspen on the west face of the stein boulder.  Directly in front of you if you come up from the big easy boulder.

content.description:
Start with a left hand gaston and your right hand on an undercling sloper. Establish the start, and make a right hand move to a crimp slot. From there, move up and a bit right to top out on slopers - the top out is very similar to

Pinchenstein

(if confused watch the beta video in the comments).
content.location:
Start in between

Gristletwist

and

Pinchenstein

.

content.description: At the offwidth crack, climb the left arete.  The cobble hole inside the crack and the right arete/side of the crack are off.  May be a little height dependent.
content.location: The route is located at the offwidth that splits the west face.
